children.name: advertise
children.definition: /ˈædvəʳtaɪz/  to tell people publicly about a product or service in order to try to persuade them to buy it, for example by showing short films on television, or by showing pictures with words in newspapers and magazines:
examples: quảng cáo
▪ There was a big poster advertising a well-known brand of cola.
▪ We are a small business so we can only afford to advertise in the local press.
be advertised on TV/on the radio
▪ ‘How did you find out about the new software?’ ‘It was advertised on TV.’
be advertised in a newspaper/magazine etc
▪ The concert was advertised in all the national newspapers.be heavily advertised be advertised a lot
▪ Young smokers tend to buy the brands that are most heavily advertised.
advertiseverb[ I or T ] quảng cáo
to make something known generally or in public, especially in order to sell it
_We advertised our car (= published a description of it together with the price we wanted for it) in the local newspaper.
_He advertises his services on the company notice board.
_I'm going to advertisefor(= put a notice in the newspaper, local shop, etc., asking for) someone to clean my house.
_There's no harm in applying for other jobs, but if I were you, I wouldn't advertisethe fact(= make it generally known) at work.

children.name: promote
children.definition: /prəˈməʊt/  to try to make people buy a new product, see a new film etc, for example by selling it at a lower price or talking about it on television:
examples: quảng cáo
▪Meg Ryan is in Europe to promote her new movie.
▪ To promote their new shampoo, they are selling it at half price for a month.
promote something as something
▪ They’re trying to promote Dubai as a tourist destination.
promoteverbENCOURAGE quảng cáo (cái gì) để bán
[ T ] to encourage the popularity, sale, development or existence of something
_Advertising companies are always having to think up new ways to promote products.
_The Institute is intended to promote an understanding of the politics and culture of the Arab world.
_Greenpeace works to promote awareness of the dangers that threaten our planet today.
_It has long been known that regular exercise promotes all-round good health.

children.name: publicize
children.definition: alsopubliciseBritish /ˈpʌblɪsaɪz, ˈpʌbləsaɪz/  to tell the public about a situation, event, organization, problem by advertising, writing, or speaking about it on television, in newspapers etc:
examples: ▪ Hollywood gossips were saying that the studio lacked the funds to publicize its new film properly.
▪ A good estate agent will know the best ways to publicize the fact that your home is for sale.
▪ A series of articles and television shows publicized concerns that the chemical Alar, used to keep apples red and firm, could cause cancer.
well-/highly/widely/much publicizedpublicized a lot
▪ Jurors were asked what they knew about the highly publicized case.
publicize,UK usuallypubliciseverb[ T ] quảng cáo
to make information about something generally available
_Attitudes seem to be changing as a result of recenthighlypublicizedcasesof sexual harassment.
_The event waswellpublicized all over town.
_The work of the charity has beenwidelypublicized throughout the media.

children.name: hype/hype up
children.definition: /haɪp, ˌhaɪp ˈʌp/  informal to try to make people interested in a product, entertainer, film etc, using television, radio, and newspapers- use this to show that you do not trust this kind of information:
examples: quảng cáo láo, thổi phồng, cường điệu
▪Like most Hollywood movies it was so hyped up that when I saw it I was completely disappointed.
▪The cosmetics industry is usually quick to hype its new products.
hyped[adjective]heavily/greatly/much etc hyped
▪ Douglas Kennedy’s hugely hyped first novel ‘The Big Picture’
hypeverb[ T often passive ](alsohype up) quảng cáo thổi phồng;cường điệu
to repeatedly advertise and discuss something in newspapers,
on television, etc. in order to attract everyone's interest
_It's being hypedasthe musical event of the year.

children.name: plug
children.definition: /plʌg/  informal alsogive something a plug/ˌgɪv (something) ə ˈplʌg/  especially British informal to try to persuade peopleto buy a book, see a film etc,by talking about it publicly,especially on television or radio:

children.name: quảng cáo
examples: ▪ The only reason she agreed to be interviewed was to plug her new record.
▪ The author used the opportunity of appearing on TV to give his latest book a plug.

children.name: sell
children.definition: /sel/to encourage people to buy something:

children.name: ăn khách, làm cho cái gì bán được
examples: ▪There’s no question about it - scandal sells newspapers.

children.name: sell something to somebody
examples: ▪ It’s not just a question of making a good product - we also have to go out and sell it to people.

children.name: push
children.definition: /pʊʃ/ informalto try to sell more of a product or service by advertising it a lot:
examples: quảng cáo , tung ra
▪Revlon is really pushing its new range of beauty creams.
pushverbADVERTISE
[ T ]informalto advertise something repeatedly in order to increase its sales
_They're really pushing their new car.

children.name: market
children.definition: /ˈmɑːʳkɪt, ˈmɑːʳkət/  to try to sell a product or service by deciding which type of people are likely to buy it and by making it attractive and interesting to them:
examples: ▪ In order to market a product well, you need to be aware of public demand.
▪ The company has exclusive European rights to market the new software.
marketverb[ T ]
to make goods available to buyers in a planned way which encourages people to buy more of them, for example by advertising
_Their products are very cleverly marketed.

children.name: merchandise
children.definition: verbUS specialized buôn bán

children.name: to encourage the sale of goods by advertising them or by making certain that they are noticed
examples: _She had to merchandise the new product line.

children.name: advertising
children.definition: /ˈædvəʳtaɪzɪŋ/the business of trying to persuade people to buy things, using pictures, words, songs etc on television and radio, large public notices, and magazines:
examples: ▪ The big cigarette manufacturers spend billions of dollars a year on advertising.
▪ CBS/FOX said that its advertising was mostly aimed at young adults between the ages of 18 and 23.
▪ Sara is looking for a job in advertising or the media.
advertising agency: a company that advertises other companies’ products : công ty quảng cáo
▪ Deutsch is the biggest advertising agency in the world.
advertisingnoun[ U ] nghề quảng cáo
the business of trying to persuade people to buy products or services
_Fiona worksinadvertising.
_the advertising industry

children.name: promotion
children.definition: /prəˈməʊʃən/  an attempt to make people buy a new product, see a new film etc, for example by selling it at a lower price or talking about it on television:
examples: quảng cáo
▪ Robbie Williams arrived in New York to do a week of promotion for his new record.
▪ The author was signing copies of his new book as a part of the publisher’s promotion campaign.
sales promotion
▪ They ran a sales promotion scheme in which a World Cup coin was given away with every four gallons of petrol purchased.
promotional[adjective only before noun] promotional video
▪ a promotional video made by the Apple Computer Companypromotional copy
▪ I managed to get hold of a promotional copy of the Manic Street Preachers’ latest album.
promotionnounENCOURAGE sự quảng cáo (hàng...)
[ C or U ] activities to advertise something
_asalespromotion
_There was a promotion in the supermarket and they were giving away free glasses of wine.
_Obviously as sales manager he'll be very involved in the promotion and marketing of the product.

children.name: marketing
children.definition: /ˈmɑːʳkɪtɪŋ, ˈmɑːʳkətɪŋ/  the business of trying to sell a product or service by deciding which type of people are likely to buy it and making it attractive and interesting to them:
examples: ▪ The business course includes classes on marketing.
marketing strategy/campaign
▪ The reason their cars sold so well was that they had a brilliant marketing strategy. :
marketingnoun[ U ]JOB sự tiếp thị
a job that involves encouraging people to buy a product or service
_a career in marketing
_Our marketing people have come up with a great idea for the launch of the new model.

children.name: publicity
children.definition: /pʌˈblɪsɪti, pʌˈblɪsəti/  the business of making sure that people know about a new product, a new film, a famous person etc, for example by talking about them on TV or writing about them in magazines:
examples: quảng cáo
▪ The show’s organizers spent over $500,000 on publicity alone.
good/bad publicity
▪ The band appeared on Larry King’s show, which was good publicity for their US tour.
publicitynoun[ U ] sự quảng cáo; sự rao hàng
the activity of making certain that someone or something attracts a lot of interest or attention from many people, or the attention received as a result of this activity
_He attracted a lot ofadverse/badpublicity with his speech about unmarried mothers.
_Her first novel was published last yearin a blaze of(= with a lot of) publicity.
_We have planned an exciting publicitycampaignwith our advertisers.
_The publicitygeneratedby the court case has given a welcome boost to our sales.
_The normally publicity-shydirector will be making several public appearances for the launch of the movie.
_The enormous publicity surrounding the case will make it very difficult to hold a fair trial.
_The pop group's arrival by hot-air balloon was just a publicitystunt(= an unusual way of attracting the public's attention) .

children.name: hype
children.definition: quảng cáo láo

children.name: advertisement
children.definition: /ədˈvɜːtɪsmənt, ədˈvɜːtəsməntǁˌædvərˈtaɪz-/something such as a large public notice, a short film on television, or a picture with words in a newspaper, that is designed to persuade people to buy something:
examples: ▪ Most car advertisements are aimed at men.
advertisement for
▪ At this time of year, the papers are full of advertisements for skiing holidays.
advertisementnoun[ C ] tờ quảng cáo; tờ yết thị; tờ thông báo
(informalad,UKalso informaladvert) a picture, short film, song, etc. which tries to persuade people to buy a product or service
_a television/newspaper advertisementfora new car
_She scanned the job/property advertisements in the paper.

children.name: commercial
children.definition: /kəˈmɜːʳʃəl/  an advertisement ontelevisionorradio:
examples: Quảng cáo ( truyền hình phát thanh )
▪ Have you seen the new Levi jeans commercial?
commercial for
▪ a commercial for low-alcohol lager
commercial breakwhen there are commercials in the middle of a programme
▪ We’ll be right back with you after a commercial break.
commercialnoun[ C ] quảng cáo trên vô tuyến truyền hình hoặc truyền thanh
an advertisement which is broadcast on television or radio
_a commercial break

children.name: campaign
children.definition: /kæmˈpeɪn, ˈædvəʳtaɪzɪŋ kæmˌpeɪn/  a planned series of advertisements for a new product or service : chiến dịch quảng cáo
examples: The company got into a lot of trouble over its last campaign.

children.name: slogan
children.definition: /ˈsləʊgən/  a short clever phrase used in an advertisement:
examples: khẩu hiệu( trong quảng cáo )
▪ a dry-cleaning company that used the slogan ‘We know the meaning of cleaning’
slogannoun[ C ] (của một chính đảng hoặc dùng để quảng cáo); khẩu hiệu
a short easily remembered phrase, especially one used to advertise an idea or a product
_an advertising slogan
_a campaign slogan

children.name: hoarding
children.definition: British /billboardAmerican /ˈhɔːʳdɪŋ, ˈbɪlbɔːʳd/  a large flat board in a public place, where large printed advertisements are shown:

children.name: biển quảng cáo
examples: ▪ Beside the freeway was a huge billboard showing an ad for Ben & Jerry’s ice cream.

children.name: junk mail  / direct mail
children.definition: junk mail/direct mail/ˈdʒʌŋk ˌmeɪl, dˈrekt ˌmeɪl/  advertisements you receive in the mail from different companies, often with special deals or sales in them. Direct mail is the word used by the companies who send out these advertisements:
examples: thư rác( để quảng cáo )
▪ Statistics show that 44% of junk mail is thrown away and never read.
junk mailnoun[ U ]thưrác (tài liệu quảng cáo...gửi qua bưu điện)
post, usually advertising products or services, whichis sent to people although they have not asked for it

children.name: infomercial
children.definition: /ˈɪnfəʊmɜːʳʃəl/  a television or radio advertisement made to look and sound like a real programme, often a financial news report or an advice show:

children.name: chương trình quảng cáo trên ti vi dưới hình thức phỏng vấn
examples: ▪ Cable channels began broadcasting the 30-minute infomercial in April.

children.name: ad
children.definition: informal alsoadvertBritish informal /æd, ˈædvɜʳt/  an advertisement:
examples: ▪ She had started her acting career by doing shampoo ads on TV.

children.name: ad for
examples: ▪ I saw an advert for some cheap furniture in our local paper.

children.name: put an ad in a newspaper/magazine
examples: ▪ We put an ad in ‘The Times’ and got a terrific response.

children.name: banner ad
children.definition: /ˈbænər æd/  an advertisement that appears at the top of a web page (=a page on the Internet), that you click on to find out more about the company, product, or service:
examples: ▪ A banner ad for NewsPage, a personalized Internet news service, appeared on part of the screen.

children.name: advert
children.definition: adinformal alsoBritish informal /æd, ˈædvɜʳt/  an advertisement:
examples: ▪ She had started her acting career by doing shampoo ads on TV.
ad for
▪ I saw an advert for some cheap furniture in our local paper.
put an ad in a newspaper/magazine
▪ We put an ad in ‘The Times’ and got a terrific response.
advertnoun[ C ]UK sự quảng cáo
an advertisement
_an advertforthe local radio station

children.name: merchandising
children.definition: noun nghề buôn, sự buôn bán
examples: products connected with a popular film, singer, event, etc., or the selling of these products

children.name: a man who works in advertising
adman
children.definition: nouninformal người chuyên viết quảng cáo, người chuyên vẽ quảng cáo, người làm nghề quảng cáo
examples: a man who works in advertising

children.name: advertiser
children.definition: noun người quảng cáo; báo đăng quảng cáo; tờ quảng cáo
examples: _Whilst claiming to promote positive images of women, advertisers are in fact doing the very opposite.

children.name: copywriter
children.definition: noun người viết bài quảng cáo
examples: someone who writes the words for advertisements

children.name: publicist
children.definition: noun người làm quảng cáo, người rao hàng
examples: someone who arranges publicity for a person or organization by giving informationtoreportersand broadcasters and arranging public meetings and special events

children.name: ad agency
children.definition: noun
examples: a company that produces advertisements

children.name: a marketing/advertising, etc. man
children.definition: a man typical of or involved in marketing/advertising, etc.

children.name: call centre
children.definition: nounUK
examples: a large office in which a company's employees provide information to its customers, or sell or advertise its goods or services by telephone

children.name: market research
children.definition: noun sự nghiên cứu thị trường

children.name: the collection and examination of information about things that people buy or might buy and their feelings about things that they have bought
examples: _Market research shows that demand for small cars will continue to grow.

children.name: market researcher
children.definition: nounnhànghiên cứu thị trường
examples: someone whose job is doing market research

children.name: selling point S
children.definition: selling pointnoun điểm đặc sắc của sản phẩm; nét đặc biệt của hàng hoá

children.name: a characteristic of a product which will persuade people to buy it
examples: _Its best selling point is the price - it's the cheapest on the market.

children.name: logo
children.definition: nounplurallogos
examples: a design or symbol used by a company to advertise its products
_a corporate logo
_The players wore shirts with the sponsor's logo.

children.name: public relations S
children.definition: public relationsnoun (abbreviationPR)
examples: mối quan hệ giữa một đoàn thể và công chúng; mối liên hệ với quần chúng
the activity of keeping good relationships between
an organization and the people outside it
_Environmentalists attacked the company's ad as a public-relationsexercise.
PRnoun[ U ]ADVERTISING
abbreviation forpublic relations
_The company's putting out a lot of PR about the new product line.
_They've decided to hire a PRfirmto improve their public image.
_a PR exercise/campaign

children.name: leaflet
children.definition: noun tờrơi

children.name: a piece of paper which gives you information or advertises something
examples: _Demonstrators handed out leaflets to passers-by.
_A leaflet about the new bus services came through the door today.

children.name: business card
children.definition: noun (alsocard) tấm thiếp nhỏ có in tên và các chi tiết
examples: về việc làm và cơ quan của người chủ tấm thiếp; danh thiếp
a small card that has your name, company name, and the job you do printed on it

children.name: trailer
children.definition: nounADVERTISEMENT đoạn phim quảng cáo phim mới

children.name: an advertisement for a film, or television or radio programme, consisting of short parts taken from it
examples: _I saw a trailerforthe latest Spielberg film.

children.name: flier
children.definition: nounINFORMATION tờ bướm quảng cáo
examples: (US usuallyflyer) a small piece of paper with information on it about a product or event

children.name: hoarding
children.definition: nounUKADVERTISEMENT pa-nô quảng cáo; biển quảng cáo
examples: (USbillboard) a very large board on which
advertisements are shown, especially at the side of a road
_an advertising hoarding

children.name: billboard
children.definition: noun bảng quảng cáo khổng lồ (đặt ở dọc đường đi hoặc trên các toà nhà)
examples: US forhoarding (ADVERTISEMENT)

children.name: handbill
children.definition: noun thông cáo phát tay;quảng cáo phát taycho những người qua đường
examples: a small printed advertisement or notice that is given to people by hand

children.name: broadsheet S
children.definition: broadsheetnounUK biểu ngữ

children.name: a newspaper that is printed on large paper, or an advertisement printed on a large sheet of paper
examples: _In Britain, the broadsheets are generally believed to be more serious than the tabloids.

children.name: launch
children.definition: nounEVENTbuổi ra mắt ( sản phẩm mới )

children.name: an event to celebrate or introduce something new
examples: _How much champagne will we need for the launch?
_Illness prevented her attending the launchpartyfor her latest novel.

children.name: subliminal
children.definition: subliminal messages and images are hidden in advertisements, pictures etc and can influence your mind without you realizing it: ngầm
examples: Any kind of subliminal advertising is illegal on British TV.
Young people are receiving constant subliminal messages glorifying pop stars, their cars, their girlfriends.
